Award.AwardTitle: Lichen biodiversity in the threatened Middle Atlantic Coastal Plain of North America: Improving classification, conservation, and communication
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lichens are fungi with a unique lifestyle involving a semi-parasitic relationship with an alga and/or cyanobacterium. Although lichens are critical to maintaining healthy ecosystems on land, they remain chronically understudied. This project centers on a survey of lichen diversity in the environmentally threatened Middle Atlantic Coastal Plain of the United States and represents an efficient, comprehensive means of addressing a critical information gap for one of the least known and most environmentally sensitive organismal groups. The survey data will be used to resolve numerous problems related to conservation and ecology through a unique system that integrates newly written computer scripts and programs.

The project will set conservation priorities in the region and will result in two book-length works on lichens. While preparing these treatments, the authors will depart from traditional approaches by using dynamic online resources to incorporate the insights of professionals and amateurs alike. The investigators will teach a series of courses, mentor a diverse cohort of high school and undergraduate students, and train a PhD student. Extensive interactions and collaborations with regional land managers and naturalists, including a three-day workshop led by the investigators, will ensure that this project has the maximum impact on conservation efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lichens are fungi with a unique lifestyle involving a symbiosis with an alga and/or cyanobacterium. Although lichens are critical to maintaining healthy ecosystems, they remain chronically understudied like most other organisms that constitute Earth’s neglected biodiversity. The central goal of this project was to complete the first large scale biodiversity inventory for lichens the Middle Atlantic Coastal Plain, a coastal region of the eastern United States recognized for its high biodiversity and globally unique ecosystems. The ecosystems and species of the Mid-Atlantic Coastal Plain have already been greatly impacted by past land use changes, so much so that many are now considered to be threatened or imperiled.

Through research carried out in the field, the lichens communities at more than 200 sites from New Jersey to Georgia were assessed by a team of ranging from experts with decades of experience to newly trained graduate students and undergraduate interns. The assessments generated more than 13,000 new museum specimens which were evaluated together with specimens that already existed in museums or were newly donated so they could be included in the project. All data were disseminated in a timely fashion and free-of-charge online, as well as provided to relevant stakeholders together with results of the project.

Training of two post-docs, two PhD students, multiple undergraduate interns and many land managers/biologists was undertaken through direct mentorship, collaboration, and through hosting multiple meetings and workshops. Extensive outreach efforts were undertaken to reach members of the public through presentations, guided nature walks, and publication of popular works online and in print as part of collaborations with several native plant societies, universities, and state governmental agencies. A total of 26 new species was described from the Mid-Atlantic Coastal Plain, eight additional species were described as part of training/mentorship projects. In addition to many scientific papers published in peer-reviewed journals the project resulted in the publication of two major floristic works, and dissemination of the first comprehensive identification keys to lichens of any portion of the southeastern Coastal Plain. The project also led to the discovery of a previously overlooked biodiversity hotspot in coastal North Carolina that is imperiled by sea-level rise.

To summarize, this project established the first baseline knowledge of lichen diversity in a region well known for its biological diversity but which is also highly threatened. The protocols and methods developed for this project established a new model for large scale biodiversity inventory of lichens that can be broadly applied elsewhere to other systems and other groups of organisms.
